data.title: TODAY IN HISTORY
data.text:
Thursday, March 18 ---1584 - Ivan IV, the first to assume the title of tsar of Russia, died. He inaugurated domestic reforms and conducted successful campaigns against the Tartars, but his cruelty and oppression earned him the nickname Ivan the Terrible. 1662 - The first buses, eight-seater vehicles known as Carrosses a Cinq Solz, ran in Paris. 1768 - Laurence Sterne, Irish-born clergyman and novelist and author of The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, died.

1837 - Grover Cleveland, twice president of the United States from 1885-89 and 1893-97, born. 1844 - Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov, Russian composer, born. As well as composing and conducting, he was also a teacher and his pupils included Stravinsky and Prokofiev. 1848 - A five-day revolution began in Milan against Austrian rule, forcing governor Joseph Radetzky to withdraw from the city. 1858 - Rudolf Diesel, German engineer and inventor of the engine that bears his name, born.

1871 - The insurrection of Paris against the French government began. The rebels, known as the Communards, were finally defeated in May. 1913 - King George I of Greece was assassinated at Salonika. 1916 - The battle of Naroch Lake, an attempt by the Russians to divert German forces from the western front, began. 1921 - Russian soldiers finally put down a rebellion by sailors at Kronstadt, the chief base of the Russian Baltic Fleet near Petrograd. 1922 - Mahatma Gandhi was sentenced to six years imprisonment for his activities against the British rule.

1932 - John Updike, American novelist, poet and critic, born. 1936 - Frederik Willem de Klerk, South African president who intitiated the reforms which led to the end of apartheid, born. 1940 - In World War II, Hitler and Mussolini met at the Brenner Pass in the Alps. It was agreed that Italy would eventually join the war. 1949 - The text of the North Atlantic Treaty was published for the first time.

1962 - The war in Algeria ended when agreements were signed with the French leading to independence from France. 1965 - Ex-king Farouk I of Egypt died in exile in Italy. 1965 - Soviet cosmonaut Aleksei Leonov made the first space walk. 1970 - Cambodian head of state Prince Norodom Sihanouk was deposed. 1977 - In Congo, President Marien Ngouabi was assassinated.

1978 - Former Pakistan Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was found guilty of ordering the assassination of an opponent and sentenced to death. 1983 - King Umberto II of Italy died in exile in Switzerland. 1990 - Christian Democrats won a landslide victory in the first Democratic elections held in East Germany. 1993 - After six days of deadlock, security forces stormed a hijacked Ethiopian airliner in the eastern town of Dire Dawa, killing two of the four hijackers.

1996 - The Palestinian authority renamed the Gaza Strip and West Bank as District of Gaza and the Northern Counties of Palestine. 1998 - A Cambodian court convicted ousted co-premier Prince Norodom Ranariddh of plotting a coup and sentenced him to 30 years in jail. 1998 - E.M.S. Namboodiripad, an 89-year-old Indian Marxist who headed the world's first democratically elected communist government, died.
